conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of objects A and B. The key is to determine when the two objects are farthest apart, which corresponds to the time when their positions are the greatest difference.
Identify the positions of objects A and B on their respective velocity-time graphs. The graph shows the velocity as a function of time.
The position is the integral of velocity over time.

premise: Since the objects start from the same position, the distance between them at any given time \( t \) is given by the integral of their velocity over time.
conclusion: Thus, the distance between them at time \( t_1 \) is \( \int_{t_1}^{t_2} v(t) \, dt \).

premise: To find the time when the objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the graph to determine when the distance between them is maximized.
conclusion: This occurs when the velocity of object A is greater than that of object B, as this means the object is moving faster and thus further ahead.
From the graph, identify the time \( t_2 \) at which the velocity of object A is greater than that of object B.

premise: Since the objects start from the same position, the time \( t_2 \) is when the distance between them is the greatest.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at time \( t_2 \).
